subject: RE: [junit] Re: JavaDocs
msgSnippet: ... yes, it does say: ...A variation of the above convention is to put all fixtures into the application package itself. This gives the fixtures access to all
messageBody:
At 11:43 AM 2/22/02 +0000, you wrote:
>Nope. Just set up two project root directories (an additional sourcepath
>entry) e.g. src & test.
>Say I have a file toplevel.nextlevel.MyClass, the production source would be
>in src/toplevel/nextlevel/MyClass.java and the test source would be in
>test/toplevel/nextlevel/TestMyClass.java
>
>Covered in the faq for Junit.

yes, it does say: ...A variation of the above convention is to put all
fixtures into the application package itself. This gives the fixtures
access to all the package visible methods and fields. To separate the
fixture classes from the production classes put them into a separate
directory that you then add to the CLASSPATH. This makes it easy to ship
the production classes independent of the fixtures

thanks

> -----Original Message-----
>From: Ray Tayek [mailto:rtayek@...]
>Sent: 22 February 2002 11:31
>To: junit@yahoogroups.com
>Subject: Re: [junit] Re: JavaDocs
>
>At 09:53 AM 2/21/02 -0800, you wrote:
> >... you can always have two source paths, one for the source and one for
> the test cases.
> >
>
>pm4ji, but are you implying that the source for test classes will be in a
>different directory?
